channel.title: ASF Jira
channel.description: This file is an XML representation of an issue

item.title: [MCOMPILER-205] incremental compilation broken for package-info classes
item.project: Maven Compiler Plugin (Moved to GitHub Issues)
item.description:
When we do clean -> compile -> compile, all Java sources are re-compiled for second compilation steps:

[framework]$ mvn clean
...
[framework]$ mvn compile
...
[INFO] --- maven-compiler-plugin:3.1:compile (precompile-sources-for-cdk) @ richfaces-framework ---
[INFO] Changes detected - recompiling the module!
[INFO] Compiling 915 source files to /mnt/workspace/workspaces/richfaces/richfaces5/framework/target/classes
...
[framework]$ mvn compile
...
[INFO] --- maven-compiler-plugin:3.1:compile (precompile-sources-for-cdk) @ richfaces-framework ---
[INFO] Changes detected - recompiling the module!
[INFO] Compiling 915 source files to /mnt/workspace/workspaces/richfaces/richfaces5/framework/target/classes
...

The source code of the affected project: https://github.com/richfaces/richfaces5/tree/077dcfc0a46d03d7ba9a7ac3e701a4adfb834c71
item.summary: incremental compilation broken for package-info classes

status.description: The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.

comments.comment: Attaching the IT from original MCOMPILER-187
The root cause of this issue seems handling of resources in src/main/java that do not end up generating a .class file under target/classes.
That make sense. Our requirement was storing the XML files side-by-side the Java files so they are easily accessible by contributors. Would you consider it valid use case?
xml files are resources, in maven world they should be stored under src/main/resources...

It's recommended, but not required, and sometimes there are different requirements.

I have this issue compiling Play! Framework project. There is requirement for all sources and resources be placed in "app" directory (see http://www.playframework.com/documentation/1.2.5/guide1 and http://www.playframework.com/documentation/2.0/Anatomy).
I'm using Maven plugin for Play! Framework (http://code.google.com/p/maven-play-plugin/) to build Play! projects.
use <excludes> to exclude those files from incremental analysis.

I've a similar problem. I've attached hello as a sample project.
When i do mvn clean compile; mvn compile nothing compiles as expected.
But when i change only one java file, plugin compiles all module.

hello$ mvn clean compile
hello$ echo " " >> src/main/java/com/mycompany/hello/Hello.java
hello$ mvn -X compile

I'm seeing same with Commons builds.

Looks like it might be due to the new way of defining Javadoc for packages:

useIncrementalCompilation enabled
Stale source detected: D:\eclipseworkspaces\main\commons-net\src\main\java\org\apache\commons\net\whois\package-info.java
Stale source detected: D:\eclipseworkspaces\main\commons-net\src\main\java\org\apache\commons\net\imap\package-info.java
Stale source detected: D:\eclipseworkspaces\main\commons-net\src\main\java\org\apache\commons\net\finger\package-info.java
Stale source detected: D:\eclipseworkspaces\main\commons-net\src\main\java\org\apache\commons\net\tftp\package-info.java

Since these never rarely generate .class files, they will always usually cause the compile to be re-run
Just to be precise, package-info.java can generate .class files, e.g. if they contain package annotations. So these sources shouldn't just be plainly neglected.

I'd forgotten about annotations.

Ordinary Java source files may depend on each other, and therefore multiple files may need to be compiled if one source file changes.

Is that true of package-info files, or are they independent?
If so, there is no need to recompile anything else if one is found to be out of date, only the p-i file itself.
This would reduce the recompilation needed.
Ideally the package-info files would not be recompiled either if they won't generate class files, but that may be much harder to detect.

Undesirable workrounds include: don't use p-i files; ensure every p-i file contains a package annotation.

Ant had an issue with the package-info.java files and solved it by creating empty class files if the javac compiler failed to do so. This is (now) optional behaviour.

See https://issues.apache.org/bugzilla/show_bug.cgi?id=52096 for a useful discussion.

It points out that JDK 7 javac has the option -Xpkginfo:always

The difference with Ant is that it does not recompile everything just because a single p-i file is out of date.
That's an optimisation that Maven could easily implement.

[For completeness]
A work-round is to ensure that p-i files always generate output.
One way to do this is to add an annotation.

Unfortunately it appears that the only annotation which is guaranteed to be available in Java 1.5+ is @Deprecated, which is obviously unsuitable. But it is possible to create a dummy annotation, as follows:

PackageMarker.java
@Retention(RetentionPolicy.SOURCE)
public @interface PackageMarker { }
package-info.java
/**
 * Example Package Javadoc
 */
@PackageMarker
package example;

This work-round is suitable for projects that have a mix of p-i files, some of which already use annotations.
Excluding the p-i files from compilation is only suitable if the p-i files contain Javadoc only.

Note that version 2.5.1 does not suffer from this problem; it only recompiles the package_info.java files - they do not cause the entire project to be recompiled.

3.0 and 3.1 are broken.
What if maven-compiler-plugin generates package-info.class files if the compilation was successful and package-info.class is missing for a particular package-info.java?

Github user kennknowles closed the pull request at:

https://github.com/apache/incubator-beam/pull/287

With useIncrementalCompilation on false, when changed sources are found, only they are recompiled.
With useIncrementalCompilation on true, when changed sources are found, everything is recompiled. Why?

The attached patch tries to only recompile the changed sources. It seems to work - but only on every second build. Someone more familiar with the code needs to have a look.
This also works: delete files named "package-info.java" from the list of stale files.
Deleting package-info.java from the list of stale files avoids recompiling the module every time, but still recompiles every file if anything changes.

instead of adding a dummy annotation to each package-info.java I changed the compiler configuration to
<compilerArgs>
<arg>-Xpkginfo:always</arg>
</compilerArgs>

which worked. Also running mvn compile -X will output which files are stale. This helped me to find an empty java file that would also be treated as stale source.

Following Damjan's comment, the understanding of useIncrementalCompilation goes against common sense:

> With useIncrementalCompilation on false, when changed sources are found, only they are recompiled.
> With useIncrementalCompilation on true, when changed sources are found, everything is recompiled.

Is that on purpose or is this a bug?

monperrus opened a new pull request #3: MCOMPILER-205 fixes incremental compilation
URL: https://github.com/apache/maven-compiler-plugin/pull/3

When useIncrementalCompilation=false, always recompile all source files.

When useIncrementalCompilation=true (default), only recompiles stale sources.

I see there's some confusion, so something needs to be changed, maybe improving documentation is good enough.
Looking at the code, you'll see that non-incremental will only look at changed sourcefiles. Incremental will also verifies if dependencies have changed and if files have been added or removed. If it has changed, it'll remove the complete classes-directory. The reason is that the default java compiler is quite fast, likely much faster than analyzing per file what to do with it.
IIUC the eclipse compiler is a real incremental compiler, so we could decide that based that based on the used compiler not to drop the classes directory.

I found jens.b's answer on Stack Overflow (also quoting rfscholte's previous comment) explains this very well.

It seems clear that the logic of the flag is not inverted. However the flag itself is not clear, since the plugin is incremental in both cases. The flag should thus be something like useSmartIncrementalCompilation or useFullDependencyChangeDetection or inverted to useNaiveIncrementalCompilation or useNaiveChangeDetection.

rfscholte, could you please clarify and expand on the following comment?

The reason is that the default java compiler is quite fast, likely much faster than analyzing per file what to do with it.

It seems that despite that comment and my attempt at explaining everything in the SO answer Didier Loiseau kindly linked, there is still confusion, as some added the following comment ("the developer" and "he" referring to rfscholte):

I think you have misread the developers comment. I was scratching my head at first but I think what he meant was that the default incremental compilation provided by javac is fast. I very much doubt he meant that recompiling everything each time you make a change is preferable. You only need a project of >100 source-files to show that's nonsense.

This is what's happening: if 1 file has been changed or removed, all files are deleted and recompiled. This is in contrast with pure incremental, because otherwise we need to analyze every other class if they use the changed class and if its change should trigger a recompilation of this file as well.

We have integration tests which show the result if we would only recompile the changed files. What's probably misleading is that IDEs can do that automatically for you, which might suggest that only recompiling changed files is enough.

Okay, so if I get this right, we could rephrase your original rationale like this:

If any source file has been changed or removed, all files are deleted and recompiled. The reason for this is that simply recompiling everything with the default java compiler is quite fast, likely much faster than the alternative:

  1. recompiling changed files,
  2. analyzing all unchanged ones to figure out which of them use the changed classes, and finally
  3. recompiling those classes as well.

Please state if that captures the intention, rfscholte. (Note that I don't want to criticize, nitpick or object. I just want to fix the lack of solid information on this topic.)

There are probably multiple strategies to come to the result, but I would do the following:
1. detect all changed files
2. analyze all sourcefiles to map all relations between classes
3. calculate all affected files
4. recompile affected files

Okay, so how about the following summary to clear up any ambiguity?

If any source file has been changed or removed, all files are deleted and recompiled. The reason for this is that simply recompiling everything with the default java compiler is quite fast, likely much faster than the alternative, which would look similar to this:

  1. detect all changed files
  2. analyze all source files to map all relations between classes
  3. calculate all affected files
  4. recompile affected files

Please explicitly confirm this, rfscholte, or rewrite it as you like. Then I'll put it into my SO answer, and then we will have fixed at least some confusion
This looks good enough to me.

Looking at rfscholte's comment

Looking at the code, you'll see that non-incremental will only look at changed sourcefiles. Incremental will also verifies if dependencies have changed and if files have been added or removed. If it has changed, it'll remove the complete classes-directory.

I'm having second thoughts about this. I have a project of 2805 source files, and with the default parameters, running mvn compile twice in a row takes the same time, logging the compilation of 2085 files each time. On the other hand, by setting the parameter to false, the second compilation finishes much faster, compiling only three files. To be clear, I'm running the commands literally one after the other, so there is no way dependencies could have changed in the interim.

Reading Robert's comment, it seems to me that with the default incremental compilation enabled, running the same command twice immediately should produce an equally short run, since no dependencies have changed nor any files added or removed, which would preserve the classes directory and short-circuit the Java compiler.

Obviously, I'm misunderstanding something - but what?

zmeggyesi running mvn compile compile should only do compilation during the first run, it would help if you define the files that have been marked as changed. Does the code contain package-info files? These are known to cause recompilation, see also MCOMPILER-368

There is another interesting case where this will produce incomplete results.

Imagine a project with two annotation processors, each with -proc:only in its own execution and the default-compile execution set to -proc:none. In my example, the first execution is immutables, the second execution is hibernate static metamodel generator. All .java files can be found at target/generates-sources/annotations. Exactly as planned.

However, the hibernate-generated .java files are marked as stale. The default-compile phase will therefore not compile those. Setting useIncrementalCompilation=false will 'fix' this problem.

 

Do you think this is working as designed or intended? For me this was suprising, as I would not have thought that the java files from the second execution would have been marked as stale.

It seems to me that Maven should treat package-info (PI) files differently.
AIUI, they cannot affect the generation of other class files.
So an out-of-date PI file should not cause all files to be recompiled.

Unfortunately there does not seem to be a standard Java compiler flag to ensure that compilation of a PI file always creates a class file.
So the other change that Maven could (should) make is to generate an empty class file if the Java compiler does not generate a PI class file.
https://github.com/apache/maven-compiler-plugin/pull/88

Build succeeded in Jenkins: Maven » The Apache Software Foundation » maven-compiler-plugin » master #6

See https://ci-maven.apache.org/job/Maven/job/maven-github/job/maven-compiler-plugin/job/master/6/

After a lot of debugging I eventually found that if I overrode the maven-compiler-plugin plugin and specified a version < 3.10.0 (ex. 3.9.0) then my warning goes away.

<plugin>
    <artifactId>maven-compiler-plugin</artifactId>
    <version>3.9.0</version>
    <configuration>
    </configuration>
</plugin>

I can't say that I understand the significance of the warning and whether it would have caused a problem for the application or not. As far as I can understand from reading this bug is that a redundant compilation BUG was fixed and an option was introduced (useIncrementalCompilation I'm guessing) but that doesn't explain to me why our project is now showing warnings or what should be done about it. Without any guidance specified in the warning I'm leaning toward falling back to 3.9.0 just to avoid the warning in the case that is indicating something that could impact the the project.

I'm posting this hear mainly because I'm fairly confident that what I'm a seeing is related to the change that was put in place for this bug/issue and I don't understand the details enough to know whether what I'm running into represents a regression in maven-compiler-plugin which may warrant a separate bug report to follow up.

Hi,

any reason createMissingPackageInfoClass is true by default?

makes it weirdish to get package-info when it is expected by javac to not get it in the final binary (once again by default).

shouldn't we set it to false for 3.11?
This project has moved from Jira to GitHub Issues. This issue was migrated to apache/maven-compiler-plugin#881.
